Rational points of elliptic surfaces and Zariski Nğ‘N-ples for cubic-line, cubic-conic-line arrangements



Shinzo BANNAI, Hiro-o TOKUNAGA and Momoko YAMAMOTO

Abstract

In this paper, we continue the study of the relation between rational points of rational elliptic surfaces and plane curves. As an application, we give first examples of Zariski pairs of cubic-line arrangements that do not involve inflectional tangent lines.

Introduction

In this article, we study the arithmetic of rational points of certain rational elliptic surfaces from a geometric point of view in order to construct arrangements of plane curves of low degree which give rise to candidates for Zariski pairs. A pair of reduced plane curves (â„¬1,â„¬2)superscriptâ„¬1superscriptâ„¬2(\mathcal{B}^{1},\mathcal{B}^{2}) is said to be a Zariski pair if it satisfies the following conditions:

  1. (i)

    For each iğ‘–i, there exists a tubular neighborhood Tâ€‹(â„¬i)ğ‘‡superscriptâ„¬ğ‘–T(\mathcal{B}^{i}) of â„¬isuperscriptâ„¬ğ‘–\mathcal{B}^{i} such that (Tâ€‹(â„¬1),â„¬1)ğ‘‡superscriptâ„¬1superscriptâ„¬1(T(\mathcal{B}^{1}),\mathcal{B}^{1}) is homeomorphic to (Tâ€‹(â„¬2),â„¬2)ğ‘‡superscriptâ„¬2superscriptâ„¬2(T(\mathcal{B}^{2}),\mathcal{B}^{2}).

  2. (ii)

    There exists no homeomorphism from (â„™2,â„¬1)superscriptâ„™2superscriptâ„¬1(\mathbb{P}^{2},\mathcal{B}^{1}) to (â„™2,â„¬2)superscriptâ„™2superscriptâ„¬2(\mathbb{P}^{2},\mathcal{B}^{2}).

The first condition can be replaced by the combinatorics (or the combinatorial type) of â„¬isuperscriptâ„¬ğ‘–\mathcal{B}^{i}. For the precise definition of the combinatorics, see [2] (It can also be found in [21]). Since the combinatorics is easier to treat with, we always consider that of â„¬isuperscriptâ„¬ğ‘–\mathcal{B}^{i}. The study of Zariski pairs was originated by Zariski in [23]. Since the â€™90â€™s there have been a lot of results on Zariski pairs by many mathematicians via various methods (see the reference [2], for example). As we noted in [2], there are two main ingredients in the study of Zariski pairs. Namely,

  1. (I)

    To find reduced curves â„¬1superscriptâ„¬1\mathcal{B}^{1}, â„¬2superscriptâ„¬2\mathcal{B}^{2} with the same combinatorics so that â„¬1superscriptâ„¬1\mathcal{B}^{1}, â„¬2superscriptâ„¬2\mathcal{B}^{2} have certain different features, and

  2. (II)

    To prove (â„™2,â„¬1)superscriptâ„™2superscriptâ„¬1(\mathbb{P}^{2},\mathcal{B}^{1}) is not homeomorphic to (â„™2,â„¬2)superscriptâ„™2superscriptâ„¬2(\mathbb{P}^{2},\mathcal{B}^{2}) based on the different feature as above.

A Zariski Nğ‘N-ple is a natural generalization, where the number of curves is increased. One of our new feature of this article concerns (I): Construction of plane curves via geometry and arithmetic of sections for certain rational elliptic surfaces. This basic idea can be found in [21] by the first autor and in [5] by the first and second authors. In this article, however, we make use of the arithmetic of sections more intensively than previous papers.

For (II), in order to distinguish (â„™2,â„¬1)superscriptâ„™2superscriptâ„¬1(\mathbb{P}^{2},\mathcal{B}^{1}) and (â„™2,â„¬2)superscriptâ„™2superscriptâ„¬2(\mathbb{P}^{2},\mathcal{B}^{2}), our tool is Galois covers branched along â„¬isuperscriptâ„¬ğ‘–\mathcal{B}^{i} developed in [5, 21]. Note that there are various other tools, for example, the fundamental group Ï€1â€‹(â„™2âˆ–â„¬i,âˆ—)subscriptğœ‹1superscriptâ„™2superscriptâ„¬ğ‘–âˆ—\pi_{1}(\mathbb{P}^{2}\setminus\mathcal{B}^{i},\ast), braid monodromy and Alexander invariants. Recently two more new tools, the linking set and the connected number, are introduced by J.-B. Meilhan, B.Â Guerville-BallÃ© [7] and T.Â Shirane [17], respectively.

We explain our object more concretely. The first and second authors have studied Zariski pairs (or Nğ‘N-ples) for arrangements of curves whose irreducible components are of low degree, less than or equal to 4, via geometry of sections and bisections of rational elliptic surfaces ([5, 21]). In this article, we also continue to study such objects. More precisely, we consider a reducible curve whose irreducible components consist of

  1. (i)

    one irreducible cubic and lines, and

  2. (ii)

    one irreducible cubic, smooth conics and lines.

In [1], a Zariski pair of sextics consisting of a smooth cubic and its three inflectional tangents was given. This example was also considered in [19] from a different approach. In [7], a Zariski pair of octics consisting of a smooth cubic and its 555 inflectional tangents is given. In [4], that of reducible curves consisting of a smooth cubic and kğ‘˜k of its inflectional tangents (k=4,5,6ğ‘˜456k=4,5,6) are considered. Note that there exist no Zariski pair of a smooth cubic and kğ‘˜k of its inflectional tangents for k=1,2,7,8,9ğ‘˜12789k=1,2,7,8,9. Also, in [3], E.Â Artal Bartolo and the second author studied a Zariski pair of sextics whose irreducible components are a nodal cubic, a smooth conic and an inflectional tangent line. All of these examples contain inflectional tangents of a cubic as irreducible components. As for another new feature of this article, we focus on Zariski pairs for cubic-line or cubic-conic-line arrangements without inflectional tangents. Also, since Zariski pairs for sextic curves have already been intensively studied by many mathematicians, e.g., [13, 14, 15], we consider the case of degree 777 as follows:

Theorem 0.1

Let â„¬1superscriptâ„¬1\mathcal{B}^{1} and â„¬2superscriptâ„¬2\mathcal{B}^{2} be as above. Then (â„¬1,â„¬2)superscriptâ„¬1superscriptâ„¬2(\mathcal{B}^{1},\mathcal{B}^{2}) is a Zariski pair.

The organization of this paper as follows: In Â§1, we give a summary on facts and previous results, which we need later. We prove TheoremÂ 0.1 in Â§2. A Zariski triple and 4-ple for cubic-conic-line or cubic-conic arrangements are considered in Â§3 and explicit examples are given in Â§4.

1 Preliminaries

1.1 Elliptic surfaces

1.1.1 Generalities

As for basic references about elliptic surfaces, we refer to [9, 10]. We also refers to [16] for general facts on the Mordell Weil lattices. In particular, for those on rational elliptic surfaces, we refer to [12]. We also use the notation and terminology used in [5, 21] freely. In this article, by an elliptic surface, we always mean a smooth projective surface Sğ‘†S with a fibration Ï†:Sâ†’C:ğœ‘â†’ğ‘†ğ¶\varphi:S\to C over a smooth projective curve Cğ¶C as follows:

  1. (i)

    Ï†ğœ‘\varphi has a section O:Câ†’S:ğ‘‚â†’ğ¶ğ‘†O:C\to S (we identify Oğ‘‚O with its image).

  2. (ii)

    There exists a non-empty finite subset, Sing(Ï†)Singğœ‘\mathop{\rm Sing}\nolimits(\varphi), of Cğ¶C such that Ï†âˆ’1â€‹(v)superscriptğœ‘1ğ‘£\varphi^{-1}(v) is a smooth curve of genus 111 (resp. a singular curve ) for vâˆˆCâˆ–Sing(Ï†)ğ‘£ğ¶Singğœ‘v\in C\setminus\mathop{\rm Sing}\nolimits(\varphi) (resp. vâˆˆSing(Ï†))v\in\mathop{\rm Sing}\nolimits(\varphi)). Note that there exist no multiple fibers since Ï†ğœ‘\varphi has the section Oğ‘‚O.

  3. (iii)

3 Zariski triple and 4-ple for cubic-conic-line arrangements

In [5], we give examples of Zariski Nğ‘N-ples for conic, conic-quartic arrangements. By similar arguments to those in [5], we give a Zarisiki triple and 444-ple for cubic-conic-line arrangements. Throughout this section, we use the terminology, notation and results in [5], freely. The combinatorics considered in this section is as follows:

In the construction of plane curves with Combinatorics 3-(a) and (b), how to find a contact conic ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C} to â„°+â„’oâ„°subscriptâ„’ğ‘œ\mathop{\cal E}\nolimits+\mathcal{L}_{o} is crucial and we make use of bisections of elliptic surfaces as we did in [5]. Let us recall that a bisection is defined as follows:

Definition 3.1
